physicalObject: black selfie stick with extendable metal rod and phone holder
utilizationMethod: Fold the rod to its shortest length, wrap your thumb around one flat side of the collapsed shaft while the four fingers close on the opposite side, lift it straight up, feel the weight, then lower it back onto the desk

virtualObjectInfo.usage: it serves as an educational teaching appliance for student to understand the concept of high density
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Users would feel the heaviness about 1kg while lifting
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users would feel the shape like a solid rectangular ingot with slightly tapered sides (trapezoidal profile)
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Because of its 1-kg apparent weight and brick-like geometry (10 cm × 4 cm × 2 cm), users will approach the bar with a power grip. The thumb opposes the four fingers along the long faces, wrapping around the tapered sides to keep the slab from slipping. Once lifted, the wrist will naturally pronate/supinate to test heft and density, and the shoulder/elbow may rise slightly to compensate for the surprising inertia. The ingot remains perfectly rigid and motionless relative to the hand—no deformation, no moving parts—so all perceived feedback comes from the user’s muscles resisting gravity. Users may also set it down with a controlled lowering motion, feeling a sharp, metallic ‘stop’ when the bottom face meets a surface.

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The canvas is not grasped; instead it receives repeated, light contact from another tool (the brush). The user guides the brush tip toward the vertical canvas plane, making momentary presses followed by gliding strokes of varying length. Contact is mainly between the bristles and the canvas surface, producing short, low-force taps and sustained lateral slides. Occasionally the user’s fingertips or knuckles may brush the edge or front while stabilizing a stroke, but most interaction is transient and low-pressure. The canvas itself does not move; it simply offers a firm, slightly textured resistance that halts the brush at the surface while allowing friction-based feedback during each glide.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: it serves as an artistic tool for painting
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: lightweight, about 10g
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users should feel a cylindrical shaped graspable part
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users hold the brush with a precision or tripod grip: thumb, index, and middle finger pinch the 1-cm-diameter cylindrical handle roughly 3-5 cm above the bristles, while the ring and little finger rest along the shaft for stability. The hand pivots at the wrist to generate strokes; fingers subtly roll the handle to vary angle and line width. Motions include tapping, dragging, flicking, and twisting. Because the brush is only about 10 g, there is minimal inertial resistance; perceived feedback comes from its rigid handle outline and the slight flex of bristles on contact with the canvas. The object itself stays rigid in the user’s grip, offering no deformation or mechanical response.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: lightweight, about 10g
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users should feel a cylindrical shaped graspable part
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users hold the brush with a precision or tripod grip: thumb, index, and middle finger pinch the 1-cm-diameter cylindrical handle roughly 3-5 cm above the bristles, while the ring and little finger rest along the shaft for stability. The hand pivots at the wrist to generate strokes; fingers subtly roll the handle to vary angle and line width. Motions include tapping, dragging, flicking, and twisting. Because the brush is only about 10 g, there is minimal inertial resistance; perceived feedback comes from its rigid handle outline and the slight flex of bristles on contact with the canvas. The object itself stays rigid in the user’s grip, offering no deformation or mechanical response.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: it serves for liquid dispensing.
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Users would perceive very light overall weight about 10g, with the center of mass positioned the lower dropper tip.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users would feel approximately 1cm of pinch distance
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: Users would feel soft and spring -back feedback, while squeezing and releasing an easily compressible part.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users pick up the dropper with a precision grip, thumb on one side of the glass tube, index and middle finger on the opposite side, positioning the rubber bulb between thumb and index. To draw liquid, they rotate the wrist so the tip points downward, then squeeze the soft bulb using a pad-to-pad pinch (thumb squeezing toward index). The bulb compresses 5-10 mm with low force and provides a spring-back sensation on release, producing a subtle suction pull perceived through the fingers. The tube remains rigid and lightweight, causing almost no inertial load. Dispensing involves slight wrist rotations and controlled bulb presses to eject droplets, with sequential squeeze-release cycles until empty.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: it serves for liquid dispensing.
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Users would perceive very light overall weight about 10g, with the center of mass positioned the lower dropper tip.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users would feel approximately 1cm of pinch distance
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: Users would feel soft and spring -back feedback, while squeezing and releasing an easily compressible part.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users pick up the dropper with a precision grip, thumb on one side of the glass tube, index and middle finger on the opposite side, positioning the rubber bulb between thumb and index. To draw liquid, they rotate the wrist so the tip points downward, then squeeze the soft bulb using a pad-to-pad pinch (thumb squeezing toward index). The bulb compresses 5-10 mm with low force and provides a spring-back sensation on release, producing a subtle suction pull perceived through the fingers. The tube remains rigid and lightweight, causing almost no inertial load. Dispensing involves slight wrist rotations and controlled bulb presses to eject droplets, with sequential squeeze-release cycles until empty.
